title: Applying data ethics
body:
In this module, we will explore the application of data ethics using tools that support individuals and organisations in developing products and services that mitigate negative risks and serve to promote positive outcomes for people and society. 

This module provides you with the knowledge and skills to:

  • Describe the types of questions to ask when embedding ethical data practices
  • Identify common barriers to adopting approaches to data ethics
  • Explain how to use tools and frameworks to support ethical thinking around collection, use and sharing of data in projects
  • Make several recommendations to improve the ethical handling of data

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: Summary
body:
Applied Data Ethics is the practice of evaluating our data practices to understand the impact of our work. This module has introduced tools that help us evaluate ethical data practices at the project level, and at the organisational level. Engaging with these tools is unlikely to remove all of the negative impacts that result from collecting, using and sharing data (or lack-of). However, they will support individuals and organisations to mitigate the negative consequences and promote more positive outcomes. 

When evaluating ethical risk, it is also important to evaluate the risk of NOT doing something. For example, what is the ethical risk of not developing a product for a specific purpose? What is the ethical risk of not sharing data with others? What is the ethical risk of not collecting data from a wide variety of different groups in society and only focusing on one?

Most importantly, make time for ethics. Invest in people, policies and processes. Also be prepared to adapt. Society changes, as will what is ethical and not. Only this investment and ability to adapt will help organisations demonstrate they are committed to their individual and organisational principles.

title: Q: Ethics and data governance
body: In addition to practical tools, what else do organisations need to provide in order to ensure data ethics is prioritised?

_items.text: Clear roles and responsibilities to manage data ethics concerns
Policies and processes that ensure data ethics is embedded in the organisation
Training for staff on how to evaluate data ethics concerns throughout the data lifecycle
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

In order to ensure data ethics is prioritised, organisations should treat it much like compliance/legal concerns and invest in people, policies and processes as well as training; tools are useless if no one takes responsibility for ensuring they are used and findings acted upon. This means that there must be clear roles and responsibilities linked to data ethics, policies and processes that ensure ethics is a primary concern throughout the data lifecycle, and training to support staff to follow policies and processes and make use of tools.

title: Q: Why do projects fail?
body: Which of the following is the primary reason that data projects fail?

_items.text: Lack of data
Issues with people and culture
Lack of processes
Lack of technology

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

63% of data project failures are due to issues with people and culture (McKinsey, 2018)

In short, if you can get people on board, you are much more likely to have positive outcomes for your data project.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

63% of data project failures are due to issues with people and culture (McKinsey, 2018)

In short, if you can get people on board, you are much more likely to have positive outcomes for your data project.

title: Q: Avoiding failure in data projects
body: In 2018, Gartner published a report that estimated the proportion of AI data projects that fail. Consider your own experience of data projects, how many do you think fail?
instruction: Drag the slider below and click 'Submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Gartner found that 85% of AI data projects fail (Gartner, 2017)

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Gartner found that 85% of AI data projects fail (Gartner, 2017)

_graphic.alt: There are two ODI tools that support project level assessment, these are consequence scanning and the data ethics canvas. For organisational level assessment we use the data ethics maturity model

title: There is never a lack of data, or technology.
body: There is never a lack of technology or data. Both are often seen as the “golden bullet” to solving a whole host of vaguely defined problems. In fact having too much technology and data can cause more problems, both legal and ethical. Too much data and technology becomes more challenging to manage, more disparate, siloed and not to mention aged and part of the legacy/debt of the organisation. Having the right processes and people in place to support the data and technologies and being focussed on your purpose will help ensure that technologies and data are suitable for the purpose and not there because it is easy to get both.

title: Data ethics tools
body: The ODI has developed and is responsible for a series of Data Ethics tools that focus on supporting individuals and organisations in embedding data ethics practices into their projects and overarching organisational strategies.

title: Project level tools
body:
Consequence Scanning Toolkit

For a quick assessment of a project, with particular emphasis on the intended and unintended consequences on people, communities and the planet. It provides an opportunity to enhance positive consequences, and to mitigate or address potential harms from negative consequences before they happen. It considers what can be acted upon, what can be influenced, and how to monitor.

Learn more about the Consequence Scanning Toolkit

Data Ethics Canvas

For deep consideration of a project. It is divided into four areas: ‘Data’, ‘Impact’, ‘Engagement’ and ‘Process’. This is a tool to focus discussions from ideation to implementation, and considers everything from purpose to effects, as well as how to monitor and iterate.

title: Organisational tools
body:
Data ethics maturity model

Unlike the other two tools, this is not intended for specific data sets, but is more overarching

Considering data ethics at project level is good, but deep and lasting developments must happen at organisation level. This is the focus of the Data Ethics Maturity Model. This tool provides a means to assess and benchmark an organisation’s effectiveness with data ethics, divided into six themes and five levels of maturity.

title: Which scenario would like to use?
displayTitle: Which scenario would like to use?
body: Choose which scenario you would like to use for the consequence scanning activity
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Scenario 1: A charitable transformation
Scenario 2: The supply and demand of taxi services

title: Unintened consequences: Act, influence or monitor?
displayTitle: Unintened consequences: Act, influence or monitor?
body:
Following the identification of consequences, the next step is to sort the unintended consequences into the following catagories:

  • Act: The things the core team can take forward and action immediately. Within these, prioritisation and time scales should be applied.

  • Influence: Consequences that need to be handled by other stakeholders, either within the organisation or externally, but within reachable networks.

  • Monitor: These are consequences that you cannot control, such as political climate or global trends.

While you could do this for the intended consequences, the ones we have listed are all in the monitor category.

_items.text: Increase in pricing disparities in communities not appropriately serviced by public transport
User journeys are tracked and potentially identifiable, with risk to personal safety
Reduced services for communities in areas deemed “low demand” where drivers are encouraged to accept fares in high-demand areas
Unintended increase in pricing in cases of extreme events (e.g. local emergencies)
Increase in vehicles on the road, increase the traffic congestion and has an environmental impact
Increase in data collection and use has an increase in the risks associated with storing and processing the data
Disparities in driver experiences based on flexibility, earnings and support. Drivers are encouraged to seek high fare periods which impacts work-life balance
Changes in legislation for gig-economy workers as "employeed" by this service

_feedback.correct:
There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. There are both positive and negative outcomes from this type of data-driven dynamic pricing model. To ensure positive outcomes and mitigate any potential harm, the taxi firm could do the following:

  • Implement a cap on surge pricing to ensure that, despite rapid increases in demand, service users are not unfairly targeted by price rises due to events out of their control.
  • Implement standardisation of direct earnings for drivers as a percentage of the base fare where drivers can earn improved fares in areas that are in low demand to support fair coverage of service. Similar processes can be applied to time of day to maintain purported flexibility in driver work/life balance.
  • Implement data collection measures for air quality and environment with incentives and appropriate support for drivers to use more environmentally friendly vehicles.
  • Implement anonymisation methods to data collected about people and their journeys. Randomisation and generalisation methods can ensure that data utility is maintained, and suppression of high risk data points can be used to maintain privacy. 

These are just a few of the possible actions that could be taken, and as you can see, not all of them are directly about data - although they may be informed by or inform what data is used, collected and shared. It may be that some of these actions are deemed low priority, and although the consequence has been identified, it is also deemed to be a low risk to the organisation. Regardless, there is plenty more work to be done to ensure positive outcomes where possible.

_incorrect.final:
There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. There are both positive and negative outcomes from this type of data-driven dynamic pricing model. To ensure positive outcomes and mitigate any potential harm, the taxi firm could do the following:

  • Implement a cap on surge pricing to ensure that, despite rapid increases in demand, service users are not unfairly targeted by price rises due to events out of their control.
  • Implement standardisation of direct earnings for drivers as a percentage of the base fare where drivers can earn improved fares in areas that are in low demand to support fair coverage of service. Similar processes can be applied to time of day to maintain purported flexibility in driver work/life balance.
  • Implement data collection measures for air quality and environment with incentives and appropriate support for drivers to use more environmentally friendly vehicles.
  • Implement anonymisation methods to data collected about people and their journeys. Randomisation and generalisation methods can ensure that data utility is maintained, and suppression of high risk data points can be used to maintain privacy. 

These are just a few of the possible actions that could be taken, and as you can see, not all of them are directly about data - although they may be informed by or inform what data is used, collected and shared. It may be that some of these actions are deemed low priority, and although the consequence has been identified, it is also deemed to be a low risk to the organisation. Regardless, there is plenty more work to be done to ensure positive outcomes where possible.
_incorrect.notFinal:
There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. There are both positive and negative outcomes from this type of data-driven dynamic pricing model. To ensure positive outcomes and mitigate any potential harm, the taxi firm could do the following:

  • Implement a cap on surge pricing to ensure that, despite rapid increases in demand, service users are not unfairly targeted by price rises due to events out of their control.
  • Implement standardisation of direct earnings for drivers as a percentage of the base fare where drivers can earn improved fares in areas that are in low demand to support fair coverage of service. Similar processes can be applied to time of day to maintain purported flexibility in driver work/life balance.
  • Implement data collection measures for air quality and environment with incentives and appropriate support for drivers to use more environmentally friendly vehicles.
  • Implement anonymisation methods to data collected about people and their journeys. Randomisation and generalisation methods can ensure that data utility is maintained, and suppression of high risk data points can be used to maintain privacy. 

These are just a few of the possible actions that could be taken, and as you can see, not all of them are directly about data - although they may be informed by or inform what data is used, collected and shared. It may be that some of these actions are deemed low priority, and although the consequence has been identified, it is also deemed to be a low risk to the organisation. Regardless, there is plenty more work to be done to ensure positive outcomes where possible.

_partlyCorrect.final:
There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. There are both positive and negative outcomes from this type of data-driven dynamic pricing model. To ensure positive outcomes and mitigate any potential harm, the taxi firm could do the following:

  • Implement a cap on surge pricing to ensure that, despite rapid increases in demand, service users are not unfairly targeted by price rises due to events out of their control.
  • Implement standardisation of direct earnings for drivers as a percentage of the base fare where drivers can earn improved fares in areas that are in low demand to support fair coverage of service. Similar processes can be applied to time of day to maintain purported flexibility in driver work/life balance.
  • Implement data collection measures for air quality and environment with incentives and appropriate support for drivers to use more environmentally friendly vehicles.
  • Implement anonymisation methods to data collected about people and their journeys. Randomisation and generalisation methods can ensure that data utility is maintained, and suppression of high risk data points can be used to maintain privacy. 

These are just a few of the possible actions that could be taken, and as you can see, not all of them are directly about data - although they may be informed by or inform what data is used, collected and shared. It may be that some of these actions are deemed low priority, and although the consequence has been identified, it is also deemed to be a low risk to the organisation. Regardless, there is plenty more work to be done to ensure positive outcomes where possible.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. When consequence scanning is applied to your own projects, you’ll have a much more granular understanding of what you can act upon, what you can influence and what you should monitor.

You can view our answer, where we think most can be proactively tackled with remiadiation and data management measures that reduce risk while still providing a fair system for both customers and drivers.

title: Unintened consequences: Act, influence or monitor?
displayTitle: Unintened consequences: Act, influence or monitor?
body:
Following the identification of consequences, the next step is to sort the unintended consequences into the following catagories:

  • Act: The things the core team can take forward and action immediately. Within these, prioritisation and time scales should be applied.

  • Influence: Consequences that need to be handled by other stakeholders, either within the organisation or externally, but within reachable networks.

  • Monitor: These are consequences that you cannot control, such as political climate or global trends.

While you could do this for the intended consequences, the ones we have listed are all in the monitor category.

_items.text: Users of the service are incorrectly profiled and unable to home an animal
Diverse range of internal users increases the number of data quality issues where data is manually created and input
Simplified processes and storage leads to overly complex permissions set up and provides disparate or inappropriate access to volunteer staff
Increased data breaches due to increase of activities undertaken on a single system
Reduced staff resource as efficiencies in practice have negative effect on individual workloads
Risk of data deletion of duplication of errors in transferring and interacting with data on a single system
Data held about individuals (personal or otherwise) is used to create profiles that are biassed
Increase in digital divide for colleagues who are not appropriately supported through large scale digital transformation

_feedback.correct:
There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. When consequence scanning is applied to your own projects, you’ll have a much more granular understanding of what you can act upon, what you can influence and what you should monitor.

Given the consequences identified (both positive and negative), we think the charity could take the following actions:

  • Define clear permissions and user groups to ensure that any access to systems by stakeholders is managed and that only relevant data can be accessed, used or shared.
  • Implement new/improved data schemas once data is consolidated to ensure that data is managed effectively and sustainably maintained in the longer term.
  • Reduce profiling activities of service users to and research additional approaches to reviewing suitability of animal adoption.
  • Improve IT security resources to ensure appropriate backup systems to reduce risk of data loss and/or breach.
  • Design and implement communication and training plans as a process of change management. The focus points should be on transparency and clarity of purpose to ensure that stakeholders understand the what, why and how of the programme and be sufficiently supported in developing new skills.

Of course, these are only a few of the actions that the organisation could take forward. Some actions are technical, while others are organisational and process-driven.

_incorrect.final:
There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. When consequence scanning is applied to your own projects, you’ll have a much more granular understanding of what you can act upon, what you can influence and what you should monitor.

Given the consequences identified (both positive and negative), we think the charity could take the following actions:

  • Define clear permissions and user groups to ensure that any access to systems by stakeholders is managed and that only relevant data can be accessed, used or shared.
  • Implement new/improved data schemas once data is consolidated to ensure that data is managed effectively and sustainably maintained in the longer term.
  • Reduce profiling activities of service users to and research additional approaches to reviewing suitability of animal adoption.
  • Improve IT security resources to ensure appropriate backup systems to reduce risk of data loss and/or breach.
  • Design and implement communication and training plans as a process of change management. The focus points should be on transparency and clarity of purpose to ensure that stakeholders understand the what, why and how of the programme and be sufficiently supported in developing new skills.

Of course, these are only a few of the actions that the organisation could take forward. Some actions are technical, while others are organisational and process-driven.
_incorrect.notFinal:
There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. When consequence scanning is applied to your own projects, you’ll have a much more granular understanding of what you can act upon, what you can influence and what you should monitor.

Given the consequences identified (both positive and negative), we think the charity could take the following actions:

  • Define clear permissions and user groups to ensure that any access to systems by stakeholders is managed and that only relevant data can be accessed, used or shared.
  • Implement new/improved data schemas once data is consolidated to ensure that data is managed effectively and sustainably maintained in the longer term.
  • Reduce profiling activities of service users to and research additional approaches to reviewing suitability of animal adoption.
  • Improve IT security resources to ensure appropriate backup systems to reduce risk of data loss and/or breach.
  • Design and implement communication and training plans as a process of change management. The focus points should be on transparency and clarity of purpose to ensure that stakeholders understand the what, why and how of the programme and be sufficiently supported in developing new skills.

Of course, these are only a few of the actions that the organisation could take forward. Some actions are technical, while others are organisational and process-driven.

There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. When consequence scanning is applied to your own projects, you’ll have a much more granular understanding of what you can act upon, what you can influence and what you should monitor.

Given the consequences identified (both positive and negative), we think the charity could take the following actions:

title: Bye bye unintended consequences?
body:
One of the important lessons here is that the recommendations and actions you derive in your discussions with stakeholders will not always lead to positive outcomes, or mitigate the negative consequences. Sometimes, it is a case of balancing the risk of the consequence and the efforts required to implement change. 

The actions we define are purely the first step. More research may be required, or preparatory activities to enable the longer term gains. Before any major changes to your working processes or project it is necessary to evaluate the potential of these actions and ensure that you do not inadvertently cause further harm or distress.

title: Summary
body:
Consequence Scanning is an agile and integrated practice within the development cycle, aimed at comprehensively assessing a project's impact on people, communities, and the environment.

By addressing both intended and unintended consequences, this tool proactively enhances positive outcomes and addresses potential negative effects. It begins with three key questions: identifying consequences, focusing on positive outcomes, and determining which consequences to mitigate. These questions encourage diverse stakeholder input for comprehensive impact mapping.

After categorising consequences as actionable, influential, or monitorable, roles and responsibilities are assigned for implementation.

Importantly, the process acknowledges that recommendations and actions may not always guarantee positive outcomes, requiring a balance between risk and change efforts. Thus, these actions serve as initial steps, with the potential need for further research and preparatory activities to avoid unintended harm during project implementation.

title: The Consequence Scanning Toolkit
body: Consequence Scanning is a dynamic and agile practice seamlessly integrated into the iterative development cycle. Its core objective is to enable organizations to conduct a comprehensive assessment of their project's impact on people, communities, and the environment, both intended and unintended. This innovative tool serves as a proactive approach to enhance positive outcomes and proactively address potential negative consequences. It involves identifying actionable insights, influencing factors, and establishing effective monitoring mechanisms, ensuring potential harms are mitigated or addressed before they materialise.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [Envato Element Licence]

title: How to use the consequence scanning toolkit
body:
You start by asking yourself three questions:

  1. What are the intended and unintended consequences?
  2. What are the positive consequences to focus on?
  3. What are the consequences we want to mitigate?

These questions help your team to share knowledge and expertise in order to map the potential impact of your work. Most importantly, these questions are designed to be asked to a varied group of stakeholders ensuring that everyone has the opportunity to input into the project.

_graphic.alt: Image shows the three key questions: What are the intended and unintended consequences? What are the positive consequences to focus on? What are the consequences we want to mitigate?
_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Intended and unintended consequences
body:
Intended Consequences:

Describe your purpose. What are you trying to achieve? What is the positive goal of the project? Who will be positively impacted?

Unintended Consequences:

Describe the potential side-effects of your project and focus on who could be negatively impacted or excluded from your project. Consider the impact on wider society, the economy, or even the environment.

_graphic.alt: Image shows six potential unintended consequences which are: Imbalance in the benefits, unforeseen uses, erosion of trust, environmental impact, changes in norms and behaviours and displacement and societal shifts.
_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Q: Publishing crime data: unintended consequences
body: What is the likelihood of the unintended consequence?

_items.text: Low
Medium
High

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Many countries have published highly detailed crime data. Although many had concerns, there has been no significant impact as a result of the data being published. People simply didn’t know what high crime was and it is more about experiences than statistics. Plus people buy houses for other reasons.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Many countries have published highly detailed crime data. Although many had concerns, there has been no significant impact as a result of the data being published. People simply didn’t know what high crime was and it is more about experiences than statistics. Plus people buy houses for other reasons.

title: Q: How would you rate the perceived negative impact?
body: How would you rate the perceived negative impact?

_items.text: Low
Medium
High

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Not being able to sell your house could cause significant harm, so the impact is at least medium, if not high.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Not being able to sell your house could cause significant harm, so the impact is at least medium, if not high.

title: Striking a balance between positive and negative impacts
body:
To assess if a potential unintended consequence is a real risk it is important to evaluate the likelihood and the severity of the impact. A common method of doing this is to complete a risk matrix and assign a risk score.

It is important to remember that while the impact of different risks could be the same, e.g. “Damage to organisation's reputation”, the likelihood and severity scores could be significantly different depending on the risk and wider context of the risk within the organisation.

It is also likely to vary widely depending on the organisation's attitude towards the risk. For example, is sharing poor quality data, which is likely most of the time, actually high in severity? Especially if you tell people the data is likely to contain errors due to the way it was collected.

title: Consequence scanning: deciding what to do
displayTitle: Consequence scanning: deciding what to do
body:
Once your team has had the opportunity to explore the intended and unintended consequences and rated those highest in risk, you can then group these consequences into the following categories:

Act: The things the core team can take forward and action immediately. Within these, prioritisation and time scales should be applied.

Influence: Consequences that need to be handled by other stakeholders, either within the organisation or externally, but within reachable networks.

Monitor: These are consequences that you cannot control, such as political climate or global trends.

From this point, you can articulate the required roles and responsibilities, allocate the actions and start implementing them against your projects.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC0]

title: Applying the Consequence Scanning Toolkit
body:
This is your opportunity to experience a consequence scanning workshop. To support your learning we’ve provided some pre-populated scenarios for you to consider and work through. 

Scenario Selection and Exploration
instruction: Your first task is to choose one scenario that captures your interest. Understand the case study and its objectives. Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Scenario 1: A charitable transformation
_items.body:
An animal charity is going through a digital transformation process. This charity supports animal care and rehoming. Therefore it holds data on the animals, the users of the service such as those who hand over animals, and those who foster or adopt, as well as data associated with volunteers, donors and broader stakeholders. 

As part of this transformation the charity wants to retire redundant platforms and consolidate all data and data processes into a single platform. This includes employee record systems, Customer Relationship Management (CRM) platforms, Volunteer Management Systems (VMS) as well as donations, animal welfare data, data supplied by local authorities and information related to internal processes and practices.

The data the charity holds includes (amongst others):

  • Financial Donors: personal details, level of involvement, etc

  • Volunteers: personal details, experience, etc

  • Adopters: potential, previous and existing. Including details of refusals and returns

  • Users: individuals who have previously handed an animal to the charity

Objective:

To reduce costs and increase efficiencies by simplifying the digital estate of the charity and reduce the redundancies in existing processes to mitigate risks. The digital transformation should maintain stakeholder privacy and maintain performance in relation to animal care.

_items.title: Scenario 2: The supply and demand of taxi services
_items.body:
A taxi firm uses data about their uses to provide personalised pricing and create a more efficient transport market where supply matches demand. The automatic pricing algorithm measures the demand in a localised area and increases the price of a fare to encourage more drivers onto the road. 

The increases in prices are temporary and applied on top of the standard fare (for example a 2x multiplier means the dynamic fare is twice that of the standard fare). To determine the dynamic pricing model the taxi firm analyses how much people are willing to pay for a certain route and uses factors such as if your phone battery is getting low, the speed which you type (including the amount of typos), walking speed and the way in which you hold your phone on any given day. 

These factors, coupled with the data about the number of rides requested, taken, cost, location and timing are all analysed together to build a predictive model.

Objective:

Dynamic pricing is intended to provide a supply and demand model that provides an effective service for customers, whilst maintaining efficient business practices.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC0]

title: The Data Ethics Canvas
body: The Data Ethics Canvas helps teams to have a guided discussion to identify the positive and negative impacts of their data project on people and society. It's a tool for anyone who collects, shares or uses data. It helps identify and manage ethical issues - in both the promotion of positive outcomes and mitigation of negative outcomes.

title: The four sections of the data ethics canvas
displayTitle: The four sections of the data ethics canvas

_items.title: Assess the data
_items.body: By asking you to assess the data sources, their limitations, the rights and legislative context of data collection, use, and share that apply to your sector.

_items.title: Identify the impact
_items.body: By asking you to identify your reasons for using data to develop this service/product, the potential positive and negative impact on people and society, and the potential approaches to minimise negative harm.

_items.title: Evaluate the engagement
_items.body: Challenges you to think about the people involved, your approaches to communication and transparency.

_items.title: Decide the process
_items.body: Helps you decide on the next steps: what should you prioritise, when will you iterate, do you need training, etc.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Putting data in data ethics
body: In relation to data, which of the following is likely to cause the biggest data ethics challenges?

_items.text: A lack of data
The quality of the data
Bias in the data
No clear rights to use the data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

There is no lack of data, in fact it is the opposite “too much data” that often leads to a greater ethical challenge. Having too much data makes it hard to manage and apply good data management principles such as quality control. A dataset can be evaluated a s high quality, but often quality does not consider bias. One of the biggest challenges arises from bias in data collection. Understanding the purpose for data collection, any targets and also the goals (or even geographic location) of the organisation that collected, stewarded the data,  will help understand if the data could be biased. 

Even the most respected research areas such as medical, have been discovered as having historical biases that mean most medical procedures are biassed toward the male anatomy.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There is no lack of data, in fact it is the opposite “too much data” that often leads to a greater ethical challenge. Having too much data makes it hard to manage and apply good data management principles such as quality control. A dataset can be evaluated a s high quality, but often quality does not consider bias. One of the biggest challenges arises from bias in data collection. Understanding the purpose for data collection, any targets and also the goals (or even geographic location) of the organisation that collected, stewarded the data,  will help understand if the data could be biased. 

Even the most respected research areas such as medical, have been discovered as having historical biases that mean most medical procedures are biassed toward the male anatomy.

title: Applying the Data Ethics Canvas
body:
The Data Ethics Canvas is a tool for anyone who collects, shares or uses data. It helps identify and manage ethical issues – at the start of a project that uses data, and throughout.

It encourages you to ask important questions about projects that use data, and reflect on the responses. These might be:

  • What is your primary purpose for using data in this project?

  • Who could be negatively affected by this project?

The Data Ethics Canvas provides a framework to develop ethical guidance that suits any context, whatever the project’s size or scope. There is guidance and support for using the Data Ethics Canvas on the ODI website, shared under an open licence.

title: Building trust through data ethics
body:
Let’s take a look at an example of the Data Ethics Canvas being used in practice.

Barclays UK wants to work with data in a way that builds trust with customers and society. They also want to document their decisions around data and data ethics in a standardised, consistent way.

It’s important for customers to trust us with their data at the same level as they do with their money.

To achieve this goal, Barclays decided to use the Data Ethics Canvas...

The Data Ethics Canvas has been fully embraced, enabling Barclays to build up a substantial library of use cases...

Barclays UK received external recognition of its work in this field, having won the ‘Best Data and AI Ethics Initiative’ category in the 2021 DataIQ Awards.

title: Summary
body:
The Data Ethics Canvas is a practical tool for guiding discussions within data project teams, assisting them in assessing the ethical implications of their work on individuals and society. It comprises four key sections that support ethical considerations from project inception through its lifecycle, prompting essential questions about data usage goals and potential harm to stakeholders.

The canvas allows the documentation of decisions, helps guide data projects, and enhances confidence and trust in ethical decision-making.

title: Data Ethics Maturity Model
body:
Unlike the other tools, the Data Ethics Maturity Model is not intended for specific data sets. Considering data ethics at project level is good, but deep and lasting developments must happen at organisation level. This is the focus of the Data Ethics Maturity Model. The tool helps assess and benchmark how widely embedded data ethics culture and practices are across your organisation.

It provides a framework to consider current performance and future ambitions, to embed a culture of ethical data practices.

The purpose of the Data Ethics Maturity Model is to:

  • Allow for an initial assessment and benchmarking

  • Provide understanding of organisation areas to focus on, actions to take, and how to monitor progress, and 

  • Provide a good practical first step for practitioners to use

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: Data Ethics Maturity Model: Themes
body:
The model introduces six themes. These themes are grouped between ‘people’ and ‘policy & process’:

People

Organisational governance & internal oversight
Strategy reflects ethical data practices. Leadership with responsibility and capacity to deliver.

 

Skills & knowledge
Identifying the learning, training and sharing required.

 

Stakeholder & staff engagement
Engagement with communities reflected in or impacted by the data.

Policy and Process

Data management risk processes
Underpinning ethical collection, use and sharing of data with focus on minimising risks of harm to people.

 

Funding & procurement
Investment in and requirements for ethical data practices.

 

Legal standing & compliance
Relevant laws, regulations and social norms.

title: Data Ethics Maturity Model: Assessment levels
body:
Across the six themes, the organisation is assessed and categorised into one of five levels:

InitialNon-existent, ad-hoc or inconsistent, with no organisational oversight.
RepeatableBecoming refined and repeatable, but only within individual teams or projects. No organisational standards.
DefinedStandards formed around internal or external best practices. Knowledge starts to be shared internally, but may still not be widely adopted.
ManagedStandards are widely adopted. Monitoring using defined metrics has begun.
OptimisingAttempting to refine and increase efficiency, and influence business sector.

title: What's next?
body:
Using the Data Ethics Maturity Model is a first step to benchmark performance. To get the most from the tool, we recommend the following:

  • Request evidence to demonstrate how each level is met, for example copies of policies, processes and role profiles.
  • Communicate your current level of data ethics maturity to your leadership team and relevant stakeholders, highlighting areas of strength and areas of weakness.
  • Set your ambition – what level of maturity do you want to achieve for each theme, and is this ambition the same for the whole organisation, or just for specific departments?
  • Create an action plan for how you will achieve your ambition, including any resources required.

title: Applying the Data Ethics Maturity Model
displayTitle: Applying the Data Ethics Maturity Model
body: Using the Data Ethics Maturity Model is a first step to benchmark performance. Using the tool below, see if you can benchmark the performance of your organisation?

_items.title: Organisational governance and internal oversight
_items.body:
1. Initial

  1. Repeatable

  1. Defined

  1. Managed

  1. Optimising

The organisation has no strategy, policy or principles that includes ethical collection, use and sharing of data

Data governance is seen as a legal issue, not a business need.


 

Individual projects or disciplines consider data ethics on an ad hoc basis.

No coherent strategy for data ethics across the organisation.


 

The organisation has a clear strategy, policy and principles that include ethical collection, use and sharing of data.

There is clear responsibility and budget support for consideration of data ethics. 

 



 

Identification and management of risks around ethical collection, use and sharing of data is a core part of the organisation's governance.

Measurable targets have been set for ethical practices and mechanisms exist for monitoring & reporting of performance.

Performance assessments of key staff are tied to delivery of objectives in the strategy or adherence to principles for ethical collection, use and sharing of data.

Efforts around data ethics, including available metrics are published and available to stakeholders. 

The organisation has a clear strategy, policy and principles that include ethical collection, use and sharing of data which is embedded throughout the organisation, from the board down, published and open to public examination.

The organisation has an ethics committee (or equivalent) to deal with decisions on ethical collection, use and sharing of data that affect the whole organisation.

Metrics monitoring ethical data practices are actively reviewed, used and adjusted over time to ensure alignment with the wider goals of the organisation.

_items.title: Data management risk processes
_items.body:
1. Initial

  1. Repeatable

  1. Defined

  1. Managed

  1. Optimising

There are no defined processes for identifying and assessing risk of harm to individuals and communities when collecting, using and sharing data.

Risks are only addressed when they threaten to become problematic for the organisation.


 

Processes for identifying and assessing risks of harm to individuals and communities when collecting, using and sharing data are ad hoc.

Risks are dealt with by individuals who care about or feel responsible for the issues, rather than in a systematic way.

Use of tools (for example Data Ethics Canvas, Consequence Scanning and the ODI’s Data Sharing Risk Assessment) to consider ethical implications from data is done on an
ad-hoc basis.

Processes for identifying and assessing risk of harm to individuals and communities when collecting, using and sharing data are standardised and include consideration of positive and negative unintended impacts.

Adoption of these processes is not universal.

Risks are prioritised based on expected impact and are dealt with in order of priority.

Use of data ethics tools (e.g. Data Ethics Canvas, Consequence Scanning or the ODI’s Data Sharing Risk Assessment) are widespread throughout the organisation.

All projects and disciplines follow processes for identifying and assessing risk of harm to individuals and communities when collecting, using and sharing data.

The organisation puts mitigation processes in place for risks that have a higher likelihood of occurring.

The organisation seeks independent validation of ethical approaches to data.

The organisation routinely assesses performance around reducing harm to individuals or communities and puts mitigation strategies in place.

The organisation monitors and adapts to changes to community norms, customs and values that influence what is considered ethical collection, use and sharing of data.

Data ethics tools have been customised for the organisation specifically and validated.

_items.title: Skills & Knowledge
_items.body:
1. Initial

  1. Repeatable

  1. Defined

  1. Managed

  1. Optimising

There is no awareness of the importance of data ethics across the organisation.

The organisation does not provide any direct support or training for staff in data ethics.

Early adoption is driven by enthusiasm of self-taught internal evangelists.

here is no shared understanding of data ethics and what it means for collection, use and sharing of data for the organisation.

Training and support for individuals/teams around data ethics is driven by the needs of specific projects.

There are individuals with a focus on ethical decision making in each discipline, but it is not commonplace for whole teams to discuss ethical collection, use and sharing of data.

The organisation relies on external expertise for guidance and practical support.

Data practitioners have a basic understanding of data ethics and what it means for collection, use and sharing of data for the organisation.

Internal peer groups and experts exist that share advice and guidance on ethical collection, use and sharing of data.

The organisation allocates budget towards basic data ethics training for all staff but training is not mandatory.

The organisation may draw on external expertise for support around complex topics and projects.

All staff have a basic understanding of data ethics and what it means for collection, use and sharing of data for the organisation.

All staff are required to undertake an introduction to data ethics training.

Data practitioners have a deeper knowledge and understanding of ethical collection, use and sharing of data.

The organisation is building internal capacity around application of data ethics guidance The organisation builds and fosters networks of expertise within the organisation and wider community.

ll staff at all levels of the organisation have a deeper knowledge and understanding of ethical collection, use and sharing of data.Staff are clear how this informs and supports organisational strategy.

Professional development of data practitioners in ethical data practices is considered a priority, and staff are encouraged to become certified data ethics practitioners.

The organisation uses its in-house data ethics expertise to provide leadership to the market, through support and guidance.

_items.title: Funding and procurement
_items.body:
1. Initial

  1. Repeatable

  1. Defined

  1. Managed

  1. Optimising

Activities to support ethical collection, use and sharing of data are unfunded.

Procurement contracts do not include requirements around ethical data practices.

The risk that suppliers use unethical practices around data is not recorded or mitigated.

Individual projects may include costs to examine potential positive and negative impacts from their collection, use and sharing of data as part of their budget.

The organisation sometimes seeks clarity around ethical data practices as part of procurement. This is driven by the needs of specific projects and is not routine.

Project funding and operational costs routinely include long term costs for assessing, building and demonstrating ethical collection, use and sharing of data.

The organisation tailors individual contracts to cover ethical data practises, as required by the needs of projects/ products.

The organisation has clarity around cost/benefits of ethical data practices.

The organisation includes standard wording in all contracts that covers ethical data practices.

The organisation proactively carries out due diligence/audit around the ethical data practices of organisations they use data from, share data with and/or who collects data on their behalf.

The organisation publishes information about cost/benefits of ethical data practices, to help others learn from their approach.

_items.title: Stakeholder and staff engagement
_items.body:
1. Initial

  1. Repeatable

  1. Defined

  1. Managed

  1. Optimising

The organisation does not communicate with customers or staff that might be impacted by data collected, used or shared.

Or

Communications around ethical data practices are dense, technical and unreadable (for example in legal language)

Communication with customers or staff that might be impacted by projects collecting, using or sharing data is ad-hoc.

Communications on ethical data practices do not use the language of the community reflected in, or impacted by, the data (for example they use internal, technical language).

Some teams/ projects begin to use feedback from communities the data is about, or who are impacted by collection, use and sharing of the data, to inform internal data management processes.

The organisation has identified a means by which individuals or communities can raise concerns around ethical collection, use and sharing of data.

The organisation has documented a repeatable approach for engaging people around collection, use and sharing of data but this is not widely adopted.

The organisation has documented how teams should use feedback from communities reflected in or impacted by data to inform their work.This is not yet widely adopted.

The organisation uses language tailored to the audience when communicating with its community.

The policy for ethical collection, use and sharing of data is published online and accessible to the public.

It is routine for all teams to engage communities reflected in or impacted by the data and to act on their feedback.

The organisation proactively seeks feedback from customers and staff on how much they trust the organisation with data about them.

The organisation shares its experience around ethical collection, use and sharing of data for example in articles, case studies or at events.

The communities reflected in, or impacted by data, are actively involved in key decisions that may affect them and decisions will not be taken forwards without consensus.

_items.title: Legal standing and compliance
_items.body:
1. Initial

  1. Repeatable

  1. Defined

  1. Managed

  1. Optimising

There is no awareness of legislative or compliance requirements to protect individuals and communities from harm.

Relevant legistlative and regulatory requirements might include human rights, data protection, anti-discrimination, intellectual property, database rights, sustainability and personal data processing.

Knowledge of legal and regulatory compliance requirements to protect individuals from harm is limited to a few individuals.

 

There is organisational guidance on compliance with legal and social requirements to avoid harm to individuals and communities, but this is not widely adopted.

 

All teams use a standardised structure for checking compliance against relevant legislation and social norms and this is measured as part of performance reporting.

The organisation proactively engages with regulators to shape future regulations and guidance to consider ethical collection, use and sharing of data.

 

The organisation shares its approach to compliance with legal and social norms in relation to ethical data practices.

Application of the organisation’s legal obligations around data collection, use and sharing are routinely reassessed and updated to reflect evolving requirements, social and political priorities.

title: How to use the tool
body:
The Data Ethics Maturity Model is designed to embed and enable a culture of discussion, awareness and interest around the issues facing ethical decisions within the data lifecycle. It is envisioned the tool be used used:

  • When first engaging with the subject of data ethics, the maturity model can be used as a support tool in conversations with teams and specific stakeholders. This can be a prompt to focus conversations on particular issues/areas, or help structure a broader discussion around current practices and policies.
  • In benchmarking departments (or teams) within the organisation against each theme to provide an overall profile for the organisation around their data ethics maturity. Engaging each department will help to highlight areas of strength as well as areas needing improvement across different parts of the organisation. This might form part of a wider data management maturity exercise.
  • To support the development of an action plan to embed ethical data practises across a department, or organisation.

It is highly recommended that senior management be engaged, from within and outside the data function, to oversee and ponsor these activities for maximum benefit and buy in.

title: Why use the tool?
body:
• Build a culture of data ethics

    Ensuring people have an appreciation of the ethical impacts of collection, use and sharing of data, and embedding this into the norms and behaviours of an organisation can help demonstrate trustworthiness with data and how they are handled. Having engaged staff, customers and stakeholders can increase the likelihood of positive impacts from data, and that unintended risks of harm to people or communities are minimised.

  • Build trust

    Organisations can use the Data Ethics Maturity Model to demonstrate to customers, staff, partners and stakeholders that their data practices are ethical, thereby building trust. Trust leads to increased willingness to share and use data, or engage with services, leading to social, economic or environmental value creation in the form of better insights, decisions, products or services.

  • Manage data ethics in the long term

    The tool can help teams consider and agree ambitions for the level of maturity of a whole organisation, or for a specific department(s). In some situations, achieving level 2 (Repeatable) or 3 (Defined) might be appropriate, whereas others – for example where demonstration of ethical values and practices is fundamental to an organisation's core values and business model – might aim for levels 4 (Managed) or 5 (Optimising) for some themes.

title: Scenario 1: Consequences
body:
To support your learning, we have provided the following intended and unintended consequences for your chosen case study. Please note, these are not exhaustive and there are many additional consequences that you may identify.

Before proceeding, take a look through these and try to identify some additional ones.

_items.title: Intended consequences
_items.body:
• Reduction of risk from old systems, including privacy, leaks and disparities in data organisation and structure
  • More effect analysis and reporting across the charity
  • Consolidation of datasets that support more effective and efficient analysis with the potential to increase the performance of charity outputs
  • Simplification of workloads and data practices for all employees, with significant benefits for volunteer stakeholders
  • Simplification of training and feedback across user groups which reduces the amount of time and resource spent on training and support
  • More effective animal support and animal placement into safe homes
  • Reduction of misplacements of animals

_items.title: Unintended consequences
_items.body:
• Users of the service are incorrectly profiled and unable to home an animal
  • Diverse range of internal users increases the number of data quality issues where data is manually created and input
  • Simplified processes and storage leads to overly complex permissions set up and provides disparate or inappropriate access to volunteer staff
  • Increased data breaches due to increase of activities undertaken on a single system
  • Reduced staff resource as efficiencies in practice have negative effect on individual workloads
  • Risk of data deletion of duplication of errors in transferring and interacting with data on a single system
  • Data held about individuals (personal or otherwise) is used to create profiles that are biassed
  • Increase in digital divide for colleagues who are not appropriately supported through large scale digital transformation

title: Scenario 2: Consequences
body:
To support your learning, we have provided the following intended and unintended consequences for your chosen case study. Please note, these are not exhaustive and there are many additional consequences that you may identify.

Before proceeding, take a look through these and try to identify some additional ones.

_items.title: Intended consequences
_items.body:
• Increase overall profits for the firm through efficiencies in employment and service offering
  • Improved access to taxi services by being more elastic and available during a 24/7 operation
  • Support long-term effective practices by identifying peaks in service requests and usage
  • Develop a better service for users by offering more choice and meeting dynamic demand
  • Reduced supply during low usage periods, reducing carbon footprint of idling
  • Increased flexibility for taxi drivers and benefits in workload management

_items.title: Unintended consequences
_items.body:
• Increase in pricing disparities in communities not appropriately serviced by public transport
  • User journeys are tracked and potentially identifiable, with risk to personal safety
  • Reduced services for communities in areas deemed “low demand” where drivers are encouraged to accept fares in high-demand areas
  • Unintended increase in pricing in cases of extreme events (e.g. local emergencies)
  • Increase in vehicles on the road, increase the traffic congestion and has an environmental impact
  • Increase in data collection and use has an increase in the risks associated with storing and processing the data
  • Disparities in driver experiences based on flexibility, earnings and support. Drivers are encouraged to seek high fare periods which impacts work-life balance
  • Changes in legislation for gig-economy workers as "employeed" by this service

title: Creating action plans
body:
Categorising the consequences into ACT, INFLUENCE, and MONITOR aids in creating focused action plans for these consequences. This helps to promote the positive outcomes but mitigate the negative potential of others.

When creating action plans it is useful to consider the following:

  • What could this mean to the consumers of your product? Have you considered security, reliability, and support?
  • What does this mean for well-being or relationships? Who else does your user experience the product with?
  • What does the consequence mean if it was applied across the world? What is the effect on different communities?
  • Are there any differences between professional and personal lives? What might this mean in different geographic contexts?

Remember, consequence scanning is a high-level and holistic approach to evaluating your data project. Actions you define at this stage do not need to be all-encompassing or solve every issue. They are to be used as an anchor point to support your future design, development, and implementation.
